resource_data.description: Here are some useful links and documents:

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript:
Welcome to the Accounting Concepts and Reporting module.

This course will cover the basic accounting principles that guide the University’s financial policies and procedures.


You can jump to a specific section of this module by clicking the menu link at the top left of the screen to open then menu, and then selecting the slide you would like to view.

If you wish to view the closed captions for this training module, click the speech bubble icon at the bottom of the player.

We have added files relevant to this training under the Resources link.

At times during this training, we may ask you to click an object on the screen to trigger an action, or click the next button to advance the course.

If you'd like to take notes, please download and print this Course Companion.

Click next when you are ready to get started.

Let’s start with some basic accounting definitions.

The Statement of Net Position or SNP reflects the overall financial position of the organization at a given moment in time.

It is also called the balance sheet.
It is the report that shows the accumulated results of all the individual years of the organization’s operations put together.
Now let’s take a look at the components of the SNP and what they mean.

They are: Assets, Liabilities and Equity or Net Positions.

The majority of these accounts are controlled by the Central Office.
An asset is a resource controlled by the organization from which future benefits are expected, for example, cash, investments, accounts receivable, inventory, capital assets, equipment, etc.
Liabilities: A liability is a present obligation of the organization arising from past events (e.g., accounts payable, accrued salaries, benefits ,vacation and debt.

Net position is the residual interest in the assets after deducting all the liabilities.

There are different categories within net position including unrestricted, restricted, expendable, and restricted nonexpendable net

Unrestricted refers to resources that are not subject to externally imposed restrictions governing their use.

Substantially all of the University’s unrestricted funds, however, are allocated for academic and research initiatives or programs, for capital projects, or for other purposes.
Restricted expendable are funds that may only be spent in accordance with the restrictions governing their use, such as endowments income or funds received from gifts.
While Restricted Nonexpendable includes the corpus of the University’s permanent endowments.

Now let’s talk about the Statement of Revenues, Expenses and Changes in Net Position or SRECNP,

It is also called Income Statement.

The components of SRECNP are:

Revenues and expenses.

These Operating Accounts” are mainly controlled by the Departments and their Units.

Revenues represent an increase in resources during an accounting period in the form of inflows.

For financial reporting revenue is classified as either operating or non-operating.

Operating revenue refers to revenue that results from the University's core mission of instruction, teaching, and public service.
Examples of non-operating revenues include State appropriations, Gifts, Pell Grants, and Investment Income.

Revenue can also come from internal or external sources.

Distinguishing between internal and external transactions is important for financial reporting

as internal transactions are eliminated and should net to zero.

It is revenue and expense to the unit, but not on a campus or consolidated financial reporting basis. An example would be a facilities work order.

External revenue is the income generated from sales and services outside of the University and is the only amount that is included for financial reporting at the University level.

Examples of external revenues are student tuition and fees, grants & contracts, and sales and services from the medical center and auxiliary enterprises such as the bookstore.

Now let’s take a look at Expenses.

Expenses represent a decrease in resources during an accounting period in the form of outflows.
Approximately 70% of the University’s operating expenses are for compensation, including salaries and benefits.
Other types of operating expense include purchases of goods and services the university buys from outside entities and depreciation

Business transactions are events that have a monetary impact on the financial statements of an organization. When accounting for these transactions, we record numbers in two accounts, where the debit column is on the left and the credit column is on the right.

A debit is an accounting entry that either increases an asset or expense account, or decreases a liability or equity account. As we mentioned before, it is positioned to the left in an accounting entry.
A credit is an accounting entry that either increases a liability or equity account, or decreases an asset or expense account. It is positioned to the right in an accounting entry.

The totals of the debits and credits for any transaction must always equal each other, so that the accounting equation is always said to be "in balance”.

If the accounting equation were not in balance, then it would not be possible to create financial statements. Thus, the use of debits and credits in a two-column transaction recording format is an essential control for accounting accuracy.

Now let’s talk about double entry.

Double entry is an accounting term describing the method of entering transactions into the accounting records.
Entries are made into the accounting record as debits and credits.
Each accounting entry will adjust one account and have an equal but opposite effect on another account.
So that the debit account is always equal to the credit account

and maintains the accounting equation where assets minus liabilities equals net position is balanced.

There is no upper limit to the number of accounts involved in a transaction - but the minimum is no less than two accounts.
The system of double entry accounting ensures that all entries are made properly.
If the credits and debits don’t match, the accountant knows immediately that there is an error in the books.
This makes it easier to complete the financial statements.
With the University’s accounting software, most transactions today are automatically captured in the accounting system.
Often the double entry is done by the computer software in the background.

If any manually entries are made, such as a journal voucher or budget adjustment entry, the system ensures that the debits will equal the credits as most accounting software packages will not allow an unbalanced accounting entry.
The Matching principle helps to answer an important question in accounting of when transactions are recorded.
This accounting principle requires goods and services must be recorded in the year they were received or the services were performed.
And Income must be recorded in the same year as the expenses that generated the income.
At UC Davis, accruals and deferrals are recorded at the end of the fiscal year in order to record any adjustments needed to be in line with the matching principle.

Here are some examples of the matching principles:

If goods or services were received before June 30th, and the invoice for those goods or services will not post by the time the June-Preliminary ledger closes, this amount should be accrued. If there is no invoice, the estimated cost should be accrued based on the purchase order or information from the vendor.

More examples can be found on the Finance Fiscal Close website, link available on the screen.

Please click next to continue.

The chart of accounts is comprised of information fields that provide basic structure to segregate and categorize transactional and budget data, ultimately used to define, identify, categorize and sort transactions.
The Chart of Accounts allows for central and departmental reporting and analysis
Provides information needed for benchmarking and decision making, such as IPEDS and other UCD local reporting (both for public use and internal analysis).
Fund accounting is an accounting system used by non-profit organizations and governments that focuses on accountability rather than profitability.
Fund accounting is used when there are restrictions on how the organization’s funding should be spent.

In fund accounting, financial activity is recorded and reported by

•Source: who gave the institution the resources
Purpose: what the funds can be used for
Function: what activity are the funds being used, for example, instruction, research and institutional support
and natural classification, which is defined by the type of transaction, such as salaries, benefits and supplies

Here are some types of funds used at UC Davis:

Contracts & Grants

•General Funds

•Reserves

•Self-supporting Funds

•Indirect & Opportunity Funds

Student Fee Funds

•Gifts & Endowments

•Agency

The Government Accounting Standards Board, also known as GAS B, is a private organization that creates accounting reporting standards, or generally accepted accounting principles (or GAAP), for state and local governments in the United States.

GASB governs the form and content of the UCD and UCOP consolidated statements as we are a public institution.

To learn more about GASB, visit their website at www.gasb.org

Please click next to continue.

Another organization important in University accounting is the National Association of College and University Business Officers, or NACUBO.

The NACUBO’s website is another great source of industry information and training.

This concludes our course.

Please click next to continue.

Thank you for watching.

For more information , please visit the Finance and Business website.

Please click the next button to exit the course.
